dimension: Porch: ~7 blocks wide (x) × 2 blocks deep (z) × 1 block high (y). Step: 1–2 cobblestone blocks at the front center, from ground level (y=0) up to porch level (y=1).
position: Center the porch on the house’s front side, with x ranging from -3 to +3 and z = 0 or 1 (if you choose the front edge at z=1). The top surface of the porch sits at y=1.
tips: Place a row of oak_planks across the full 7-block width. Extend oak_planks 2 blocks outward (z-direction) for a comfortable front deck. Put a short cobblestone step (1 block tall) at the center front, aligned with the door position.
description: This raised porch is the entry platform, giving the build a welcoming, rustic feel. The small cobblestone step helps bridge the ground to the deck.

structure: Lower Wall Frame and White Infill
dimension: Overall 7×7 footprint continues behind the porch. The wall height is 3 blocks (from y=1 to y=4).
position: Build directly behind and above the porch, starting at y=1. Extend walls around the perimeter, leaving a 5×5 interior if the walls are 1 block thick.
tips: Outline the corners and edges with spruce_planks “beams.” Fill the spaces between beams with quartz_block. If you want windows or a doorway, leave 1×2 or 2×2 openings.
description: This step creates the sturdy, half-timber style ground floor. The white quartz_block panels contrast with the dark spruce frame for a classic cottage look.

dimension: Narrower upper portion that sits at y=4 through y=5, usually centered on the front/back. Possibly 1–2 blocks inset from the lower floor’s perimeter (if you want a slight overhang).
position: Placed above the lower walls, from y=4 to about y=5. The front face might protrude to align with the roof’s gable.
tips: Build a short “second floor” or attic front with spruce beams on the edges and quartz in the middle. Allow for a small upper window if desired (e.g., 1×1 or 2×1 opening). This portion helps shape the roofline and adds a second story illusion.
description: The partial second level or attic area gives the house a cozy, layered profile, typical of medieval or fantasy cottages.

dimension: Overhang covers a 7×7 area plus 1-block extension on each side, for ~9×9 total. Height from y=5 to ~y=8 or y=9 at the highest ridge.
position: Base of roof sits at y=5, overlapping the top edges of the walls/attic. Slopes inward to meet at the center ridge.
tips: For each side, step the nether_bricks upward by 1 block as you go inward, creating a symmetrical A-frame. Extend the roof 1 block beyond the walls on the left/right sides for an authentic overhang. The front portion has a gable that frames the attic window.
description: The dark nether_bricks roof contrasts strongly with the lighter walls. Its steep pitch fits medieval or rustic themes, and a small front gable gives character.
